We have found that a similar feature in DevCreek has turned out to be
quite useful. We have a simple alert in our Eclipse plug-in that can
warn you if you haven't run a test within a configured amount of time.
We also have a graphic representation of the last few hours of
testing activity. So you can see when you last ran a test, how long
you have been fixing a test, and an impression of your recent testing
rhythm.

For screen shots of the test run ticker:
https://community.devcreek.com/space/David+Jones/blog/2007-03-26_1

And you can see the website view based on actual testing:
https://devcreek.com/principalActivity/TestCreek/DGJ

The alerts in combination with the graphics activity summary do seem
to be useful for both guiding the adoption of a TDD style, and also
for highlighting to the more experienced tester when they have drifted
from their preferred style such as when one gets lost in the debugger
for hours rather than writing a new test.

One feature that we have talked about about implementing in the past,
would be to publish these graphics traces of testing activity rhythms
for beginners to use then as exemplars to work towards. Perhaps even
some silly scoring mechanism to rate how close you measure to your
favourite star tester.

Another direction could be for the expert experimenting with altering
their testing and development practices to collect a series of
recorded traces as one record and measure of their exploration as they
weigh up the pros/cons of the variations they have tried.


Cheers
David Jones
